subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Names for Parameterized Tests (was: TestNG 4 and Data Providers)
msgSnippet: ... It s my turn to go huh, Cedric... how would invoking run on one instance cause it to run other instances? A TestRunner has Tests. It calls run(TestResult)
messageBody:
On 10/19/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Still, if you're calling run(), it means you already have an instance of
> your test, right? And then, the test methods will all be invoked on
> different instances than the one you invoked run() on...

It's my turn to go huh, Cedric... how would invoking run on one
instance cause it to run other instances?

A TestRunner has Tests. It calls run(TestResult) on them. It makes
instances once. It can call run(TestResult) as many times as it wants
to, without creating the instances again.

TestResults have references to the tests in them. So they can provide
a failing TestCase instance so that you can call run() directly on it,
allowing just the one instance to run again.

It's not that this is a big deal or anything, it's just that it's
convenient. In TestNG, you would need a way to identify exactly the
test that failed... with parameterised tests, that means you need to
identify the parameter. That wouldn't be hard either: add an index to
the report or something.
